abstract.p: David L Gold letter disputes December 31 article on tribute to late Francis E Sommer, who supposedly spoke 94 languages (S)

block.p: ''To Masters of Language, a Long Overdue Toast'' (Education page, Dec. 31), about a tribute to the late Francis E. Sommer, who supposedly spoke 94 languages, does not distinguish between linguists and polyglots.

A linguist is a student of linguistics, the scientific study of language. A polyglot knows many languages. Linguists are not necessarily polyglots, nor is the reverse true. The competence of linguists is not measured by the number of languages they know.

''To Masters of Language, a Long Overdue Toast'' (Education page, Dec. 31), about a tribute to the late Francis E. Sommer, who supposedly spoke 94 languages, does not distinguish between linguists and polyglots.

A linguist is a student of linguistics, the scientific study of language. A polyglot knows many languages. Linguists are not necessarily polyglots, nor is the reverse true. The competence of linguists is not measured by the number of languages they know.

The article uses words like fluent, learn and master. But when do those words apply? When a person can order a meal in a restaurant? Explain how a computer works? Write poetry? Achieve something even higher?

The saying ''Jack of all trades, master of none'' applies here. The more languages one ''knows,'' the less well one can know of each. ''Mastering'' a language means knowing everything there is to know about it as well as understanding, speaking and writing it to perfection. Under that definition, no one has mastered even one language.
DAVID L. GOLD Oakland Gardens, Queens, Jan. 1, 1998
